title: The Old Man Who Made Withered Trees Bloom
author: Traditional

content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling river, there lived an old man named Taro.
He was kind and gentle, with a heart as warm as the morning sun, and hands that had spent many years tending to the earth.
But though Taro was loved by all, there was one thing that made the villagers whisper when they thought he wasn’t listening—his garden.
You see, Taro’s garden was not like the others.
While the villagers’ gardens burst with bright flowers, plump vegetables, and fruit trees heavy with sweet offerings, Taro’s garden was filled with withered trees.
Their branches were twisted and bare, their leaves long fallen, and no matter how much he watered them or sang to them at night, they refused to bloom.
The children of the village sometimes giggled as they passed by, and the adults shook their heads, saying, "Poor Taro.
Even the earth has turned its back on him."  But Taro never let their words trouble him.
Every morning, he would rise with the birds, put on his wide straw hat, and tend to his garden with the same care he had given it for years.
He would whisper to the trees, "Do not worry, my friends.
One day, you will remember how to bloom."  One evening, as the sun dipped below the hills and painted the sky in shades of pink and gold, an old woman appeared at Taro’s gate.
She was bent with age, her back curved like a bow, and her clothes were patched and faded.
In her hands, she carried a small, gnarled stick—no thicker than a finger—and her eyes, though tired, sparkled with a strange, knowing light.
"Good evening, Taro," she said in a voice like dry leaves rustling.
"I have traveled far, and I am weary.
Might an old woman rest in your garden for the night?"  Taro, who had never turned away a soul in need, bowed deeply and said, "Of course, honored guest.
My home is humble, but you are welcome to stay as long as you like."  The old woman smiled, her wrinkled face crinkling like crumpled paper.
"You are kind, Taro. But I do not need your home—I only need your garden.
And in return for your kindness, I will give you a gift."  Before Taro could ask what she meant, the old woman hobbled over to the nearest withered tree.
She raised her gnarled stick and tapped the trunk three times, whispering words that sounded like the wind through dead branches.
Then, to Taro’s astonishment, a single green bud appeared on the tree’s bare limb.
It swelled before his eyes, unfurling into a delicate pink blossom that shimmered in the fading light. Taro gasped.
"How… how did you do that?"  The old woman chuckled.
"Some things only need a little magic—and a little faith." She turned to him, her eyes twinkling.
"You have cared for these trees when no one else would.
You spoke to them with kindness when others laughed. That is a rare and precious thing.
Now, watch."  She moved from tree to tree, tapping each one with her stick.
With every tap, buds burst forth, blossoming into flowers of every color—pink, white, crimson, and gold.
The garden, which had been silent and still for so long, suddenly hummed with life.
Bees buzzed lazily from flower to flower, butterflies danced in the air, and the sweet scent of blossoms filled the evening breeze.
Taro’s heart swelled with joy. He fell to his knees, tears streaming down his face. "Thank you," he whispered.
"Thank you, thank you!"  The old woman placed a gentle hand on his shoulder.
"The magic was always within these trees, Taro.
You simply needed to believe in them—and in yourself." She straightened then, her form shimmering like mist in the moonlight.
"I must go now.
But remember: kindness is the greatest magic of all."  And with that, she vanished, leaving behind only the faintest trace of stardust in the air.
The next morning, the villagers woke to a sight they could scarcely believe.
Taro’s garden, which had been a tangle of withered branches just the day before, was now the most beautiful in the village.
Trees heavy with blossoms lined the path, their petals drifting to the ground like soft rain.
The children who had once laughed now stood in awe, their mouths open in wonder.
The adults, who had once shaken their heads, now bowed deeply to Taro, ashamed of their doubt.
From that day on, Taro’s garden became a place of joy and wonder.
People came from far and wide to see the trees that had once been withered but now bloomed with life.

And Taro, who had never sought fame or riches, simply smiled and said, "All it took was a little faith—and a little kindness."  And so, the old man who made withered trees bloom taught the village a lesson they would never forget: that even the most hopeless things can flourish when tended with love.
Now, close your eyes, little one, and imagine Taro’s garden in your dreams.
Picture the blossoms swaying in the breeze, the bees humming their gentle song, and the old man smiling as he tends to his trees.
And remember—no matter how small or forgotten something may seem, it is never too late for magic. Goodnight.
